prompt: Evaluate how Native American societies adapted to the presence of European colonists in North America from 1500 to 1754.
source: AP® United States History 2025 Scoring Guidelines (Set 2)

generalNotes: Each rubric row is scored independently unless otherwise stated.
Historical evidence must be accurate and defensible; minor factual slips are acceptable if they do not undercut the argument.
Minor grammatical issues are tolerated so long as they do not obscure the argument.

criteria.title: Thesis / Claim
criteria.description: Responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
earningNotes: Thesis must appear in either the introduction or conclusion in one connected location.
Statement must identify at least one relevant development or category of analysis tied to Native adaptations.
Acceptable lines of reasoning may emphasize alliances, trade, cultural adaptation, resistance, or other defensible categories.
sampleEarns: “While some Native nations leveraged alliances with Europeans to strengthen their position, others doubled down on Indigenous networks to resist colonial encroachment.”
“Native Americans balanced selective adoption of European goods with the preservation of cultural traditions to survive the colonial era.”
sampleMisses: Restatements of the prompt with no reasoning (e.g., “Native peoples adapted in many ways.”).
Claims that are not historically defensible (e.g., “Native Americans never changed their societies in response to Europeans.”).

criteria.title: Contextualization
criteria.description: Describes a broader historical context relevant to Native American societies and European colonization.
earningNotes: Context may come from developments before, during, or after 1500–1754 if clearly tied to the prompt.
Acceptable contexts include pre-contact trade networks, European religious and imperial rivalries, or early colonial ventures that shaped later interactions.
Must go beyond a passing phrase; should describe a development or process.
sampleEarns: “Maize agriculture supported complex trade routes across North America before Europeans arrived, giving Native societies leverage in early exchanges.”
“The Columbian Exchange unleashed diseases and new animals that forced Native communities to rethink settlement patterns.”
sampleMisses: Irrelevant references such as the Declaration of Independence.
Passing mentions with no elaboration (e.g., “There were many tribes before colonization.”).

criteria.title: Evidence
criteria.description: Uses specific historical evidence to address how Native American societies adapted to European colonists. One point for identifying at least two relevant examples; two points for using them to support an argument.
earningNotes: Evidence must fall within the geographic and chronological scope (North America, 1500–1754).
Qualifying examples include the fur trade, Covenant Chain alliances, Pueblo Revolt, Columbian Exchange adaptations, mission settlements, imperial wars, etc.
To earn two points, the response must explicitly connect evidence to an argument about adaptation (commerce, diplomacy, resistance, cultural change, etc.).
sampleEarns: “The Haudenosaunee negotiated the Covenant Chain with the British to secure trade advantages, showing diplomatic adaptation.”
“Mission settlements in New France demonstrate selective adoption of Christianity, while uprisings like Metacom’s War highlight resistance.”
“Adopting horses after the Columbian Exchange transformed Plains hunting practices, revealing technological adaptation.”
sampleMisses: Using evidence outside the time/place (e.g., Cahokia).
Repeating facts provided in the prompt without adding specificity.
Listing isolated facts with no link to adaptation.

criteria.title: Analysis & Reasoning / Complex Understanding
criteria.description: Uses historical reasoning (comparison, causation, CCOT) to frame the argument (1 pt) and/or demonstrates complex understanding through nuanced analysis or extensive evidence (2 pts).
earningNotes: First point: argument must employ a reasoning skill to organize ideas (e.g., comparing Spanish vs. French relations, explaining causes/effects of adaptation).
Second point: show sophistication such as addressing multiple perspectives, connecting across regions, or weaving together ≥4 pieces of evidence in a nuanced claim.
Complexity must extend beyond a single sentence; it should enhance the overall argument.
sampleEarns: Explains both accommodation and resistance, tying each to specific colonial powers and outcomes.
Connects Plains horse cultures, eastern fur trade diplomacy, and Southwest revolts to argue that adaptation strategies varied with local conditions.
Links developments before and after 1754 to show continuity and change in Native sovereignty efforts.
sampleMisses: Listing evidence without explaining how it supports the argument.
Referencing reasoning words (“cause,” “compare”) without actually performing the analysis.
